user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ConsoleTask_Entry:
```c
static void *OS_ConsoleTask_Entry(void *arg)
{
    OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t           local_arg;
    OS_impl_console_internal_record_t *local;
    OS_object_token_t                  token;

    /* cppcheck-suppress unreadVariable // intentional use of other union member */
    local_arg.opaque_arg = arg;
    if (OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_REFCOUNT, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONSOLE, local_arg.id, &token) == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        local = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_console_table, token);

        /* Loop forever (unless shutdown is set) */
        while (OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState != OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER)
        {
            OS_ConsoleOutput_Impl(&token);
            sem_wait(&local->data_sem);
        }
        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }
    return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ConsoleTask_Entry:
typedef union
{
    void *           opaque_arg;
    OS_ArgCallback_t arg_callback_func;
    osal_id_t        id;
    osal_index_t     idx;
} OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t
...
typedef struct
{
    sem_t data_sem;
} OS_impl_console_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_console_internal_record_t OS_impl_console_table[OS_MAX_CONSOLES]
...
void OS_ConsoleOutput_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    size_t                        StartPos;
    size_t                        EndPos;
    size_t                        WriteSize;
    OS_console_internal_record_t *console;

    console  = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_console_table, *token);
    StartPos = console->ReadPos;
    EndPos   = console->WritePos;

    OS_BSP_Lock_Impl();

    while (StartPos != EndPos)
    {
        if (StartPos > EndPos)
        {
            /* handle wrap */
            WriteSize = console->BufSize - StartPos;
        }
        else
        {
            WriteSize = EndPos - StartPos;
        }

        OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(&console->BufBase[StartPos], WriteSize);

        StartPos += WriteSize;
        if (StartPos >= console->BufSize)
        {
            /* handle wrap */
            StartPos = 0;
        }
    }

    OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl();

    /* Update the global with the new read location */
    console->ReadPos = StartPos;
}
...
extern OS_SharedGlobalVars_t OS_SharedGlobalVars
...
#define OS_SHUTDOWN_MAGIC_NUMBER 0xABADC0DE
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I reviewed the provided function and related symbols for constructs that are explicitly documented compiler language extensions (examples: GNU __attribute__ or __extension__, asm/inline assembly, statement-expressions ({ ... }), typeof/__typeof__, nested functions, label-as-values (&&label), attributes, or other vendor-specific builtins). None of these are present in the code fragments you supplied.

Specific observations supporting no-report:
- No use of compiler-specific keywords or builtins such as __attribute__, __asm__, __typeof__, __extension__, __builtin_*, or similar constructs.
- No statement-expression GCC extension ({ ... }) or nested functions are used.
- The union (OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t) is standard C; while reading a different union member than last written can have implementation-defined semantics in some contexts, it is not a compiler-specific language extension (and the code contains a cppcheck suppression comment, not a compiler pragma/extension).
- POSIX APIs and types (sem_t, sem_wait, size_t) are standard platform APIs, not language extensions; their usage is not a compiler language extension per se.
- Macros (e.g. OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET) and pointer arithmetic/indexing are standard C constructs.

Because Rule 1.2 requires reporting only when compiler language extensions (explicitly documented as such) are used, there are no suspicious fragments to report from the supplied code.
